alternative_title: Employers' tax and reporting for guarantee payments
body:
$!Guarantee payments count as earnings.$!

If you pay an employee on a day when they don't work (and it isn't a paid holiday) this is called a 'guarantee payment'.

Your employees may be entitled to these payments if you don’t give them work on a day when their contract would normally require them to work.

You need to:

+ add the payment to your employee’s other earnings
+ deduct and pay PAYE tax and Class 1 National Insurance contributions through payroll

##Technical guidance

The following guides contain more detailed information:

+ [employment protection legislation: Employment Rights Act 1996](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/manuals/eimanual/eim02550.htm "Employment protection legislation: Employment Rights Act 1996"){:rel="external"}
+ [Class 1 National Insurance: guarantee payments](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/manuals/nimmanual/nim07006.htm "Class 1 National Insurance: guarantee payments"){:rel="external"}

*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
*[PAYE]: Pay As You Earn
